thread.title: Theatre will stage fictional assassination of Katie Hopkins - in the form of a musical

author: Alex Richards
title: Theatre will stage fictional assassination of Katie Hopkins - in the form of a musical
text:

The news a Welsh theatre will stage a fictional assassination of Katie Hopkins has raised an eyebrow from the controversial Devon celeb herself. 
The Assassination of Katie Hopkins by Chris Bush and Matt Winkworth opens at Theatr Clwyd, near Mold, in April 2018. 
Akin to an episode of Charlie Brooker's Black Mirror , the play wants to explore issues of 'truth, celebrity and public outrage.' 
But Hopkins, who grew up in Bideford and lives in Exeter, tweeted yesterday that the production was: "An invitation. In every sense." 
Speaking with The Guardian, Chris said that, while fictional, the work will be presented as if it is a piece of verbatim theatre. 
Chris said: “She is someone who generates very, very strong opinions, positively or negatively, and what interests me as a writer is challenging assumptions.” Katie Hopkins 
“I disagree with the vast majority of what Katie Hopkins has to say. Politically I could not be much further from where she is on a spectrum. 
“Whether she is useful or has any right to say what she says is a much more complicated question.” 
Katie Hopkins, recently sacked by LBC Radio but continues as a Mail Online columnist, will not be portrayed by an actor, instead her death will be the trigger for the storyline. Read More Katie Hopkins is planning a nationwide tour of schools - and people aren't happy! 
It may be based on the broadcaster and former Apprentice candidate, but the death of a controversial public figure echoes the street parties held following the death of Margaret Thatcher in 2013. 
Hopkins has recently been busy reaching out to schools for an upcoming tour and has promoted the Q&A sessions on Twitter. Katie Hopkins 
She plans to discuss everything from Brexit to the Black Lives Matter movement with children aged between 11 to 16 years old. 
A leaflet she shared on Twitter describes it as “an opportunity to look at the information we are fed, to challenge the views we hold and to understand opinions are never right or wrong. Read More
